coredata.dc:title: Large MCHF calculations on the electron affinity of boron
coredata.dc:creator: Sundholm, Dage
Olsen, Jeppe
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The electron affinity (EA) of boron is evaluated by large-scale multiconfigurational Hartree-Fock calculations. A newly developed finite-element MCHF program allowing very large CI expansion is used. Systematic studies of the convergence of the electron affinity with respect to the size of the active space are reported. The obtained theoretical value is 0.2668 (30) eV compared to the experimental value of 0.277 (10) eV.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 172, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 24August 1990 lutions (1], the hydrogen bonds are evidently not an important factor for the anharmonicity. The bond distances in the crystal hydrates are slightly shorter than the calculated ones in all three cases (tables 1 and 2). The largest difference is found for mercury as would be expected from a larger cor- relation error. The observed a values include the integrated ef- fects of all the populated vibrational modes in the system, as well as contributions from other sources of distortion. To calculate all vibrational contribu- tions to the mis deviations would be an overwhelm- ing undertaking. However, it seems reasonable to as- sume that the main characteristics of the difference between the complexes should be described by the Jahn Teller active asymmetric E~mode considered here. We have thus calculated the contributions from the first four vibrational levels in E8 symmetry at room temperature (assuming a Boltzmann distri- bution) for the Zn and Hg complexes. The calcu- lated rms deviations (a~ in table 2) are about a fac- tor of two smaller than the observed a values, which is not surprising since only one vibrational mode is considered in the calculations. It may therefore be more illuminating to compare their ratios. The ratio of the calculated a8 values of the Hg and Zn com- plexes is 1.3, and the ratio of the corresponding ob- served a values is 1.44(15). It should be noted that a a0 ratio of 1.44 applied to the harmonic ~(E8) fre- quency of the zinc complex would correspond to about 171(18) cm for the mercury complex, while our theoretical (SCF) value is 184 cm . Based on the calculated and observed ratios, it seems reason- able to conclude that there is a substantial contri- bution from the SOJT effect to the a value in the mercury case. In particular, it is not necessary to as- sume a non-regular average distribution of the Hg O distances to explain the large experimental a val- ues in solution. Divalent mercury often forms, in contrast to zinc and cadmium, two short and strong bonds to sulphur ligands in the solid phase. In fact, no compound with six Hg S bond in a regular hexacoordination is known, although approximately tetrahedral four-co- ordination is common for all three ions [10,111. It is thus reasonable to assume that the ligand-induced tendency to distortion of an octahedral coordination is greater for the softer sulphur ligands than for those coordinating through the harder oxygen atom. Our calculations on the [Hg(H2S)6]2~ complex verify that this is indeed the case, although a regular hexacoordination still gives the lowest energy in our model. The calculated E8 vibration is only 94 cm , however, and may well turn imaginary in a more refined calculation. The ratio between the calcu- lated o~ values for the [Hg(H2O)6J2~ and the [Hg(H2S)6]2~ complexes is 1.2, which would cor- respond to an increase in the mis amplitude and give an experimental a value of least 0.15 A for the Hg S bonds. It is also possible that a hexasolvated com- plex would in fact distort to an average configuration with two short (or two long) opposite Hg S bonds. It should be noted that the vibrational frequencies calculated for the [Hg(H2S)6]24 complex (table 2) correspond to lower force constants than for the hy- drated complex due to the mass difference between H2S and H20. The dissociation energy D0 is much smaller with hydrogen sulphide as the ligand than with water in the hexacoordinated complexes (table 2). This will also affect the stability relative to a tetrahedral co- ordination, and it is possible that the most stable configuration in solution would actually be the te- trasolvate, [Hg(H25)4}2t. 4. Concluding remarks The results of the present study provide a strong indication that the hydrated mercury (H) ion has on the average a regular coordination in solution. The unusually large mis deviations observed by X-ray diffraction methods for the Hg-.O bonds in solution can be explained in terms of the second-order Jahn Teller effect, i.e. a vibronic coupling mainly between a vibrational E3-type mode and an excited state with an open d orbital on the Hg-atom. The longer mean Hg O distances observed in solution than in solids can be explained by assuming a larger anharmon- icity. Several observed effects indicate that cova- lency becomes more important for the hydrated mer- cury complex than for the corresponding zinc and cadmium ions, and the present theoretical results are compatible with this interpretation. According to the calculations, a regular structure has the lowest energy also for the hexasolvate 53 Volume 172, number CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 24August 1990 [9] P.-A. Bergstrom, J. Lindgren and M. Scand, A 32 (1978) 109;A41 (1987) 113. [3611. Persson, Acta Chem. Scand.A 36(1982)7. [Hg (H2S )6 12+, despite an increased vibronic cou- pling. The calculated vibrational frequency for the Ectype asymmetric vibrational mode is very low, however, only 94 cm in our model, and it is pos- sible that this configuration would not be the most stable in a more refined model or in a solution. Spin orbit interactions have not been discussed in the present study, and clearly the spin orbit effect contributes more or less to all of the observed phe- nomena. However, the observations considered in the present study can be interpreted without re- course to spin orbit effects, and in particular the sec- ond-order Jahn Teller effect can be used to explain most of the observed difference in the rms devia- tions of the Zn O and the Hg O bonds. Letters 83 (1981)391. 54 Volume 172, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETI ERS 24August1990 and O. Tapia Department of Physical Chemistry. University of Uppsala. Box 532, S-751 21 Uppsala. Sweden Received 12 March 1990; in final form 11 June 1990 Model representations of the electric field calculated with SCF ab initio wavefunctions have been constructed with the distrib- uted muttipole approach and effective point charges. Extended basis sets have been used to make benchmark catculations of the dipole, the quadrupole and the octopole moments of a water molecule, and the electric field on several grids around it. Two model representations of the charge density are tested: the distributed multipole-rcpresentation approximation and discrete point-charge approach. Comparisons are made with fields obtained from standard basis sets (6-31G, 6-31G1, 6-31G11, 3-210, 3-2H? and the minimal basis set STO-3G) and point-charge models commonly used in molecular simulations of water (TIP3P, ST2, SPC, TIP4P, Kollman s 5 charges, Dacre s model, MCY and CPC models). 1. Introduction Modelling the electric field outside an anisotropic charge density is a problem of current interest not only in classical molecular dynamics (MD) but also in microscopic quantum-chemical theories of sol- vent effects [l 3] - In the past, electrostatic inter- actions between highly charged species have been usually represented with rather unrealistic dielectric models (for a review see ref. [4]), that fail to de- scribe the anisotropic response of the microscopic polarizable media. In order to obtain a better de- scription of interactions between ions, zwitterions, On leave from: Laboratoire ECPM, Batiment 430, Campus d Orsay, 91405 Orsay, France. 2 On leave from: Chinoin Research Centre, P.O. Box 110, 1325 Budapest, Hungary. highly polar molecules, proteins and other type of bimacromolecules, reaction field effects have to be properly treated. In principle, such effects can be rig- orously incorporated in MD simulations [5) by us- ing analytical first- and second-energy derivatives re- cently reported by us for the polarization model of many-body interactions of molecular aggregates [61. Since it is the electric field which is the source of po- larization, its accurate determination is required both in classical and quantum-chemical contexts. For simple molecules, such as water, charge den- sities and their molecular properties can be quan- tum-mechanically determined with fairly high pre- cision. The accuracy attained is a function of the basis set and of the method selected to obtain the wave- function. Such calculations are used as benchmarks. Model representation of a molecular charge density has been one of the problems faced in the simulation 55 0009-2614/90/S 03.50 1990 Elsevier Science Publishers BY. (North-Holland) Modelling the electric field of water obtained from accurate SCF wave functions F. Colonna Dynamique des Interactions Moleculaires, Universite de Pierre et Marie Curie, ERA 271, 4 place Jussieu, Tour 22, 75252 Paris 05, Cedex France .LG. Angyan 2 Laboratoire de Spectrochirnie Moleculaire, Universite de Pierre et Marie Curie, 4 place Jussieu, 75252 Paris 05, Cedex France Hess Dunning Jeziorski-~ van Kernen OH 0.9454 0.9421 0.9461 FlOH 106.00 105.45 106.17 dipole 0.77 0.77 0.80 9~ 1.93 1.93 197 9~ 1.78 1.84 1.83 Q~ 1.83 1.87 1.90 Q~ 3.11 3.20 3.14 L7nz 1.28 1.33 1.24 E E~ 0.00 23.5120 4.0364 24 August 1990 Volume 172, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS rupole and octopole moments are presented in table 1. These results can be compared with those calcu- lated with an extended TZ2P + diffuse basis set by Lee [30]. The entries obtained with Dunning s basis compare well with Lee s results (0.9404 A, 106.4 , respectively). Jeziorski s basis yields slightly worse results. The dipole moment calculated with a practically near-Hartree Fock-limit wave function [31] yields 0.77 au (1.95 D) using the geometry optimized with Hess basis set. The dipole moments calculated with Dunning s and Hess basis sets are in a good agree- ment with this value. The difference of 0.04 au with respect to the experimental 0.727 au (1.847 D) [261 should be attributed to correlation effects. The geometry and dipole moment obtained with the standard basis sets are all less accurate than those determined with Hess or Dunning s basis sets. The dipole moment is overestimated, although the quad- rupole moments appear to be closer to the experi- mental value than those obtained with the extended basis sets. Nevertheless, one can note a systematic deviation from the experimental values [27,28], even when the best basis sets are used. In view of the special selection of polarization Table 3 Optimized geometries (in A), energies (in mhartree) and mul- tipoles moments up to octopole of water molecule computed with the three large basis sets at SCF level. OH is the O H distance, HOH is the water valence angle in deg. ~ is the difference between the energy calculated with the current basis set and that calculated from Hess basis set (EH~,,= 76.OS9S457 hartrec). Experimental OH =0.9572 A, HOH=104 .52 [26]. Multipoles are defined with respect to the center of mass of the molecule. For each basis set, the corresponding optimized geometry is used. The experimental dipnle= 0.727 au [27], and quadrupole [28]: 9,,= 1.96 au, o~= 1.86 au. The Hartree Fock-lirnit total en- ergy is 8 mhartree below Hess [29] of complex systems using simple analytical potential functions. Several authors have tackled the problem by using distributed multipole analysis [7 13]. These are expansions that can describe electric multipole moments, the electrostatic potential and field cre- ated by the molecular charge distribution nearly as accurately as the full charge density derived from the many-electron wavefunction. In molecular mechan- ics, molecular dynamics or Monte Carlo simulations of large and complex molecules, other researchers have advocated the use of potential derived atomic-charge models 114 18] obtained with nu- merical-fitting techniques. In this work, an extensive comparative study for a water molecule is reported which is aimed at testing the quality of these two kinds of representation of the charge density in cur- rently used models. 2. Comparison of different basis sets The calculations have been carried out at the Har- tree Fock level. Two groups of basis sets have been considered. The first group has three basis sets (Dunning [19],Jeziorski [201 andHess [21]) con- taining a relatively large number of primitive Gaus- sian functions. Dunning s basis is a (6, 2, 1, 1, 1/4, 1,1/2,1) for oxygen and (3,1,1/2) forhydrogen; Jeziorski s one is a (6, 2, 2, 1(4, 2, 1/1, 1) and (4, 2/1) for O and H, respectively. The largest basis of this group, which has been used as standard through- out this work, has been proposed recently by Hess and coworkers. This is a (6, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1(4, 2, 1, I / 1, 1) and (4, 2/1, 1), respectively. The isotropic part of the basis, a (1 3sSp) and (6s) Gaussians for oxygen and hydrogen respectively, has been taken from Van Duijnevelt [22] ~ . This basis set has been extended with a set of (2d) and (2p) polarization functions, with exponents minimizing the dispersion and complementary exchange energies, which ap- pear in symmetry-adapted perturbation theories of inter-molecular interactions [24,25]. The second group contains standard bases: 6-31G, 6-31 G*, 6- 31G**, 3-21G, 3~2lG* and the minimal basis set STO-3G. Equilibrium geometries, molecular dipole, quad ~ Tables 8.76.2 and 1 .4t.2 oriel. 123). 56 Basis iSO 4p STO-30 11.2 (5.1) 28.1 (14.8) 3-21G 9.8 (4.4) 12.6 (8.7) 3.210* 5.2 (2.4) 1.4 (5.6) 6-31G 11.5 (5.7) 1.9 (21.0) 6.310* 4.0 (1.9) 6.6 (4.1) 6.31G** 3.8 (1.2) 5.8 (3.6) Jeziorski Van Hernert 0.3 (0.2) 3.3 (0.6) Dunning 1.0 (0.4) 0.5 (1.8) Volume 172, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 24August 1990 functions made for Hess basis set and the results commented on above, the electric field calculated with this basis set has been chosen as the benchmark. The magnitude and orientation of the field have been computed on 961 randomly and uniformly distrib- uted points on a sphere around the oxygen atom of 3 A radius for all basis sets retained here. These 961 points, were determined after projecting the coor- dinates of the oxygen atoms of a shell of an equili- brated sample of water molecules onto spheres of de- sired radius. To analyze how much a field differs from the reference field, we calculate the average of the differences in magnitude z~p (~\p= < lOO( EI IL rI )/IEI>, where Eis the calculated field and E. the reference field) and also the average of the dif- ferences in orientation aG of the two fields. The re- sults are given in table 2, the standard deviations are given in parentheses. The results obtained with Dunning s basis set show nearly the same behavior as the field calculated with Hess basis. The deviation is somewhat larger for Je- ziorski s basis, although the corresponding root mean square (rms) is small. These basis sets in many re- spects are equivalent; thus one may assume that er- rors bounds within 3% in the magnitude and 10 in angular distribution are acceptable for a good model field. Although the 6-31G basis is quite popular and ex- tensively used to parametrize force fields, the results obtained with it are quite bad showing an rms de- viation in magnitude of the order of 27%. The an- Table 2 Average differences in orientation (M in deg) and in magnitude (ap, in percent) between ab initio fields and the reference field computed on a spherical grid of 961 randomly distributed points at 3 A around the water molecule. The reference field is the field computed with Hess basis set, Standard deviations are shown in parentheses gular behaviour is also poor (12 ). As one would expect, the STO-3G results differ widely from the reference field. The 6-3 lG** results differ by nearly 6% in magnitude and 4 in angular distribution, i.e. the rms fluctuations, compared to extended basis sets, are significantly larger. One can see that inclusion of polarization functions on both first- and second-row atoms is unavoidable if relatively accurate fields are required. 3, Simplified charge-density models 3.1. Distributed multipole models The electric field is given as the expectation value of the electric-field operator E(r) = fdr T( r r ) xp(r ), where T(r r ) is the electric field kernel function defined by T( r r ) =VT(r r ) = VI (r r ) , V is the gradient operator acting on the r-variable; p ( ) is the standard total-charge den- sity operator. In the linear combination of Gaussian- orbital approximation, one gets for the electronic contribution E(r) = < WIE(r)I !P> Jdr <~T(r r )p(r )IW) t { P,~,,} are the matrix elements of the first-order den- sity matrix; each factor in the product XM(r )x~fr ) is a sum of primitive Gaussian-function products. The nuclear contribution to the field is trivially com- puted. For the electronic part, the general product theorem for Gaussians centered at R,. and R8 is used. A new center follows from the product theorem, i.e. Rp=(aR,.+ssR8)/(a+ss) with a and ss represent- ing the exponents of two primitive Gaussians, r =R~+r~. Expanding T(r r ) in Taylor series around these new centers (r =R~ + rp), we obtain the field corresponding to the full multipolar expan- sion of the charge overlap associated with a given wave function. The maximum order of the non-zero multipole components depends on the highest spher- ical harmonics in the basis set. The magnitude and orientation of the field have been computed on 961 randomly and uniformly distrib- uted points on a sphere around the oxygen atom of 3 A radius for all basis sets retained here. These 961 points, were determined after projecting the coor- dinates of the oxygen atoms of a shell of an equili- brated sample of water molecules onto spheres of de- sired radius. To analyze how much a field differs from the reference field, we calculate the average of the differences in magnitude z~p (~\p= < lOO( EI IL rI )/IEI>, where Eis the calculated field and E. the reference field) and also the average of the dif- ferences in orientation aG of the two fields. The re- sults are given in table 2, the standard deviations are given in parentheses. The results obtained with Dunning s basis set show nearly the same behavior as the field calculated with Hess basis. The deviation is somewhat larger for Je- ziorski s basis, although the corresponding root mean square (rms) is small. These basis sets in many re- spects are equivalent; thus one may assume that er- rors bounds within 3% in the magnitude and 10 in angular distribution are acceptable for a good model field. Although the 6-31G basis is quite popular and ex- tensively used to parametrize force fields, the results obtained with it are quite bad showing an rms de- viation in magnitude of the order of 27%. The reference field is the field computed with Hess basis set, Standard deviations are shown in parentheses gular behaviour is also poor (12 ). As one would expect, the STO-3G results differ widely from the reference field. The 6-3 lG** results differ by nearly 6% in magnitude and 4 in angular distribution, i.e. the rms fluctuations, compared to extended basis sets, are significantly larger. head.ce:title: Large MCHF calculations on the electron affinity of boron

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, University of Helsinki, Et. Hesperiank. 4, SF-00100 Helsinki, Finland
Theoretical Chemistry, Chemical Centre, University of Lund, P.O. Box 124, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The electron affinity (EA) of boron is evaluated by large-scale multiconfigurational Hartree-Fock calculations. A newly developed finite-element MCHF program allowing very large CI expansion is used. Systematic studies of the convergence of the electron affinity with respect to the size of the active space are reported. The obtained theoretical value is 0.2668 (30) eV compared to the experimental value of 0.277 (10) eV.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Numerical determination of the electronic structure of atoms, diatomic and polyatomic molecules
